channel.description: Recent content in Reviews on Sci-fi Books Club

item.title: The Legacy of Heorot book review
item.description:
The Legacy of Heorot was published back in 1989. Written by powerhouse duo Larry Niven and Jerry Pournelle (with a bit of help from Steven Barnes), it tells the tale of a group of humans who endure a ten-year frozen trip out to a new planet to start a human colony.

Spoilers ahead

item.title: Pandora's Star book review
item.description:
Pandora’s Star is a beloved space opera novel by British author Peter F Hamilton and the first in his epic Commonwealth series of books. Coming in at a whopping 768 pages, it’s about 3x the length of a typical novel. Can it live up to the hype?

Spoiler review

item.title: Star Trek: Picard: The Last Best Hope book review
item.description:
When Una McCormack was selected to write the first tie-in novel for Star Trek: Picard, one could only imagine the pressure she must have felt. The Last Best Hope is a prequel to the TV series and tells the story of how the plan to evacuate Romulus went so wrong.

Spoilers ahead!

item.title: Night Train to Rigel book review
item.description:
Space trains.

Those two words compelled me to pick up a secondhand copy of Night Train to Rigel by Timothy Zahn. At the time I’d just moved to Sydney with my wife â€” we were house hunting, I was searching for a co-working space and adjusting to a new life in a new city. I suppose, to help me deal with all the stress, I was looking for a fun read… 300 pages of entertaining escapism.

Enter the first entry in Mr Zahn’s Quadrail series.

Spoilers ahead

item.title: Foundation book review
item.description:
Books donâ€™t get much bigger than Asimovâ€™s Foundation. Awarded â€œBest All-Time Seriesâ€ in 1966, Foundation was a trailblazer â€” some say it even invented the space opera genre. Needless to say, itâ€™s difficult not to have high expectations.

Spoilers ahead.

item.title: The Mote In God's Eye book review
item.description: Published in 1974, The Mote In God’s Eye was a runaway success. It fused the space opera of Star Trek, the world-building of Dune, and the militaristic elements of Starship Troopers. It’s 537 pages of space-faring goodness. And if you think Europe has a lot of museums, just wait until you get to Mote Prime. Unlike Star Trek, Dune and Starship Troopers, The Mote In God’s Eye shows its age. Race still divides people.

item.title: Star Trek: Voyager: Homecoming and The Farther Shore book review
item.description: After seven long years stranded in the Delta Quadrant, Janeway brought her crew back to the little blue planet she, and so many of her crew, called home. And cut. Draw the curtains and clean the stage. Voyager is home. Of course, all good Trek geeks turn to the books to continue the events once the show ends. Thus, Voyager’s relaunch is here, and veteran author Christie Golden is in charge.

item.title: Star Trek: The Next Generation: Death In Winter book review
item.description:
DNA thieves, Beverly Crusher’s maiden name and a few guest appearances from the USS Stargazer. Can author Michael Jan Friedman maneuver the Star Trek TNG books into this new era?

Spoilers ahead!

item.title: Star Trek: Titan: Taking Wing book review
item.description:
Riker finally gets that 4th pip and has left The Enterprise to captain The Titan. Can this book of new diverse characters find its feet and deliver a compelling read?

Spoilers ahead!

item.title: Star Trek: Titan: The Red King book review
item.description:
Star Trek Titan finally hits warp speed in this direct follow-up to book #1 Taking Wing. Launched into the far reaches of a satellite galaxy, can Riker steer his crew to safety?

Spoilers ahead!

item.title: Picard: Second Self by Una McCormack book review
item.description:
Following on from the success of her season 1 prequel novel, The Last Best Hope, author Una McCormack returns to the world of Picard with Second Self â€” a new novel set between seasons 1 & 2 of the TV show. After several delays the novel has finally seen the light of day. So, was it worth the wait?

Spoilers ahead!

item.description:

Spoiler review: God Emperor of Dune

item.title: Star Trek: Articles Of The Federation
item.description:
Join your favourite Federation political characters Jed Bartlet, CJ Cregg, Josh Lymen and grumpy old Toby Ziegler as they navigate the pitfalls and challenges of running a massive multi-planetary political juggernaut. Oh waitâ€¦ is this The West Wing or Star Trek?

Spoilers ahead!

item.title: Heretics of Dune book review
item.description:
Heretics of Dune continues the long and sometimes bizarre Dune saga, which began with Frank Herbert’s original Dune, written in 1966. After the lacklustre snoozefest that was God Emperor of Dune, I was hoping this book would lift the franchise near to its potential. And you know what? It kinda did.

Spoilers ahead!

item.title: Star Trek: Titan: Orions Hounds book review
item.description:
Now that the Dominion War is over, Starfleet can get back to good old exploration. Will Riker and his team of diverse Starfleet personnel must now face a band of space whalers, who aim their long harpoons at the poor old Space Jellies from TNG season 1 episode 1.

Spoilers ahead!

item.title: Star Trek: The Next Generation: Resistance book review
item.description:
The Borg are back. But this time they are faster, meaner and more adaptable. Will their new queen ascend to the throne and doom Earth to assimilation?

Spoilers ahead!

item.title: Star Trek: The Next Generation: Q&A Book Review
item.description:
When Q comes on the TV, I groan and think oh great this one is a Q episode… Can Keith R.A. DeCandido do the near-impossible and write a decent Q novel?

Spoilers ahead!

item.title: Star Trek Discovery: Wonderlands by Una McCormack book review
item.description: A year is a long time. That’s how long Michael Burnham was trapped in the 32nd century before Discovery and her crew finally emerged from the cosmic soup of space/time. So, what did Michael get up between season 3, episode 1 and season 3, episode 2 of Star Trek: Discovery? Let’s find out.

item.title: Star Trek: The Next Generation: Before Dishonor book review
item.description:
The Borg are back… again. And they’re hungry. They’re eating starships. They’re eating planets. They’re back for revenge. And now only Seven of Nine can stop them, with a little help from her friends.

Spoilers ahead!

item.title: Star Trek: Titan: Sword of Damocles book review
item.description:
In Greek literature, there was a man who coveted the king’s position. So the king agreed to let the man experience what it was like to have power. When the man took a seat at the throne, the king arranged to have a sword dangling above the man’s head, held in place by a single thread. In this Titan novel, the sword is “Erykon’s Eye”, and it dangles above an entire planet, threatening to unleash its awesome wrath. And Titan is caught in the crossfire.

Spoilers ahead!

item.title: Star Trek: The Next Generation: Greater Than The Sum book review
item.description:
Star Trek fans criticised previous relaunch books for their inconsistencies in tone, character, and direction. Can Christopher L. Bennett tie together the previous books, set up the forthcoming Destiny trilogy, and save the litverse from ruin?

Spoilers ahead!

item.title: Star Trek: The Next Generation: Destiny Trilogy book review
item.description:
The epic Star Trek: Destiny trilogy is finally upon us. This three-book, litverse crossover will shape the enter Star Trek shared continuity for years to come. David Mack has promised a truly epic, game-changer event with these books. This is a clash of civilizations: The Borg v The Federation. Who will win?

Spoilers ahead!

item.title: Star Trek: The Next Generation: Losing the Peace book review
item.description:
On Star Trek: The Next Generation, when Picard became Locutus and helped slay thousands at Wolf 359, that double episode was followed up with the episode Family, in which he travels to France to spend some time with his brother, of whom he does not get along with. William Leisnerâ€™s Losing The Peace is that kind of follow-up, giving the readers a moment to breathe after the epic events of Star Trek: Destiny.

Spoilers ahead

item.title: Star Trek: A Singular Destiny book review
item.description: The Federation must deal with the fallout from the explosive events of Star Trek: Destiny. Poor President Bacco has developed a 24 hour migraine as she tries to patch the Federation back together. Who does she call? Why, none other than Earthâ€™s resident problem solver and people persuader, Sonek Pran. The only battles in this book will be diplomatic ones. Star Trek: A Singular Destiny by Keith R.A. DeCandido offers a thoughtful epilogue to Destiny and also sets up some future storylines.

item.title: Star Trek: Titan: Over A Torrent Sea book review
item.description: Christopher L Bennet and I got beef. Of course, he wouldn’t know me from a bar of soap. But reading through the post-Nemesis Star Trek litverse, I’ve now read 14 books in the series. And I hate to say it, but Bennet is my least favourite Trek writer. Over A Torrent Sea, published in 2009 and the fifth Titan spinoff, is the perfect example of why Bennet and I don’t gel.

item.title: Star Trek: Voyager: Full Circle book review
Star Trek: Voyager: Unworthy book review
item.description: There is something to be said for getting back to the status quo. Namely, putting the Voyager crew back into their original seats… more or less. With Full Circle, author Kirsten Beyer sent the U.S.S. Starship Voyager hurtling back to the Delta Quadrant, thanks to some mean and lean slipstream technology. But the crew were still fractured, physically and emotionally â€” what will it take to bring Starfleet’s finest back to the adventure?

item.title: Star Trek: Titan: Synthesis book review
item.description:
William T. Riker and the diverse crew of the U.S.S. Titan are back, this time in the hands of British author James Swallow. Following on from the lackluster Over A Torrent Sea (by Christopher L Bennet), I was hoping that Mr. Swallow could inject some fun and action into this spinoff book series. Did he succeed?

Spoilers ahead

item.title: Star Trek: Voyager: Children of the Storm book review
item.description:
Following up from two popular and successful Voyager novels, author Kirsten Beyer is back with her third post-Destiny Voyager instalment. Children Of The Storm takes place concurrently with the previous novel, Unworthy. Can Beyer score a hat-trick with book #3?

Spoilers ahead

item.title: Typhon Pact #1: Zero Sum Game book review
item.description:
Hot off the heels of his wildly successful Star Trek: Destiny trilogy, David Mack kicks off the Typhon Pact series with Zero Sum Game. In it, Julian Bashir teams up with his former love interest, Sarina Douglas, to infiltrate the Breen and destroy the stolen quantum slipstream prototype.

Spoilers ahead!

item.title: Typhon Pact #2: Seize The Fire book review
item.description:
Author Michael A. Martin returns to Star Trek: Titan with Seize The Fire. The Gorn have joined the Typhon Pact, but they have a problem. Their warrior caste hatchery world has gone kablooey, and it’s nigh-impossible to find another suitable location. Lucky for them, they have a big ol’ terraforming device lying about. But Riker isn’t so keen on the idea of them using it…

Spoilers ahead!

item.title: Star Trek: Typhon Pact #3 Rough Beasts of Empire book review
item.description:
The third book in the Typhon Pact series is here. Rough Beasts of Empire was written by David R. George III back in 2011. It’s a book of two parts: the first focuses on Benjamin Sisko (from Deep Space Nine) in the post Destiny era, and the second focuses on Spock and his quest for the reunification of Vulcan and Romulus.

Major spoilers ahead for both this book and Deep Space Nine (the tv series)

item.title: Star Trek: Typhon Pact #4 Paths of Disharmony book review
item.description:
The Typhon Pact saga continues! Published in 2011, Paths of Disharmony explores the complex political machinations of Andor, a founding member of The Federation.

Spoilers ahead

item.title: Voyager: The Eternal Tide book review
item.description: Janeway is back! No, that isn’t a spoiler â€”Â because she is on the front cover. The Eternal Tide continues Kirsten Beyer’s series of Voyager novels, which continue the story after the TV show’s finale. Spoilers ahead First things first, this is one helluva Star Trek book. Kirsten Beyer takes the extra time and puts in a little extra thought â€”Â perhaps even love â€” into each Voyager book she writes.

item.title: Star Trek: Voyager: Protectors by Kirsten Beyer book review
item.description:
Kirsten Beyer is back with yet another Star Trek: Voyager novel. Protectors finds Admiral Janeway sent back to Earth for psych evaluations, while Chakotay and crew head out to re-investigate the spatial anomaly from the second season episode Twisted, in which Voyager encountered an anomaly which twists and distorts the ship’s internal layout.

Spoilers ahead

item.title: Book review - Star Trek Titan: Fallen Gods by Michael A. Martin
item.description:
Author Michael A. Martin returns to pen another Star Trek: Titan novel, Fallen Gods. The book is a direct sequel to his previous novel, Typhon Pact: Seize The Fire, and continues overall Typhon Pact arc.

Spoilers ahead!

item.title: Shadows Have Offended book review
item.description:
Itâ€™s been a while since weâ€™ve had a TV-era Star Trek: The Next Generation novel hit the shelves. Shadows Have Offended is author Cassandra Rose Clarkeâ€™s Trek debut and features a story involving art theft, strange diseases and Picardâ€™s impatience with Lwaxana Troi.

Spoilers ahead

item.title: Lucifer's Hammer book review
item.description:
Humanity is about to go the way of the dinosaur. A mass extinction event is cruising through space, and its name is Hamner/Brown. When the apocalypse arrives, how will humanity deal with the fallout? Water vaporised, endless salt-water rain, earthquakes…

Hide your kids, hide your wife. The comet is coming.

Spoilers ahead!

item.title: Star Trek: Deep Space Nine: Revenant book review
item.description:
Jadzia Dax, a joined Trill with all the memories of her previous hosts, catches up with her old pal Etom Prit. Heâ€™s got some bad news â€” his granddaughter Nemi has gotten into some strife, and heâ€™s calling in a favour. In trying to find and help Nemi, Dax finds herself on Trill, embroiled in crime, politics, coverups and hidden agendas.

Full review: spoilers ahead.

item.title: Footfall book review
item.description: Written in 1985, Footfall is an epic story of alien invasion. Niven & Pournelle write big books; the kind of books that would make an effective doorstop for even the heaviest of doors in the windiest of cities. Footfall, featuring dozens of characters and multiple, interweaving storylines, feels a lot like an epic movie. It’s hard not to compare it to the Roland Emerich school of storytelling; Indendepence Day in particular feels heavily influenced by Footfall.

item.title: Ghost Riders In The Sky by Timothy Zahn review
item.description:
In 2020, veteran sci-fi author Timothy Zahn dipped his toes into self-publishing for the first time, releasing the original novella Ghost Riders In The Sky. Zahn is the author of the Quadrail books, the three Cobra trilogies and more recently the Sybils War trilogy, just to name a few. However, he is perhaps best known for his Star Wars tie-in novel series Heir To The Empire.

Spoilers ahead!
